item.title: How pollen evidence can help us to rebuild paleo-environment
item.description: This week, I read the Fire and flood management of coastal swampen abled first rice paddy cultivation in east China (Linchao H. et al). I think this paper could be an excellent case study on how to use pollen evidence to rebuild paleo-environment. What can we tell from this chart? I edited the chart from the paper for better illustration Phases A and G : High frequencies of marine and brackish water diatoms and estuRINE NPMs - estuarine environments

item.title: !A review on the domestication of six domestic animals
!Tibit
Mount Tambora: the eruption that changed history
item.description: The photo came from https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/458646957 Mount Tambora erupted in 1815 with a VEI-7. The scale of it? Colossal! It reduced the global temperature by 0.7 degree Celsius in the coming year. This is an eruption that changed history. Severe famine and social chaos in Europe because of crop failure Mass migration to US during 1816-1821, which laid foundation for the development of US

item.title: The domestication of Guinea Pig
item.description: Following is my presentation on the zooarchaeology class lectured by Dr. Dong Ningning Prelude A 1610s painting by Jan Brueghel the Elder, one of the earliest portraits of guinea pig in Europe. Before being a pet Introduction of Guinea Pig Zooarchaeology Zooarchaeological evidence on the domestication of Guinea pigs Click here for full PDF

item.title: !!catalhoyok
item.description: Çatalhöyük Location: A large tell site (13 hectares) in Central Anatolia. Two mounds, of which : 34 acre East mound Neolithic Archaeologist: 1960s. James Mellaart | 70% cattle bones. Biased （hand collection instead of sieves) 1993 Ian Hodder | cattle constitute 20-25% of the faunal assemblage, and there is no indication of domestication. Date: 7 400-6 200 cal. BC. 7100-6000BC Peak Population : 3500-8000 Secular Life: 1.

item.title: !!Yinxu
!Isotope
Hominids, Hominioid, Hominines, Hominins: What’s the difference?
item.description: Hominids, Hominioid, Hominines and Hominins? When I first come up with these terms, I was quite confused and found it hard to distinguish one from the other. After reading the paper Human Evolution: Taxonomy and Paleobiology, I decide to write this article and introduce you these terms under new taxonomic classification system which based on molecular evidence. First of all, let me show you the chart, to make things easier. This chart is drawn based on the taxonomy table illustrated in Human Evolution: Taxonomy and Paleobiology.

item.title: Why is phytoliths relatively less effective than pollen evidence in terms of paleovegetation reconstruction
item.description: Phytoliths is a good alternative to pollen in the paleovegetation reconstructions, especially in the conditions where pollen evidence is badly preserved. Archaeologists can distinguish different types of phytoliths according to their shapes. However, further anaylsis is confined by the fact that, in most cases, a specific shape of phytoliths does not correspond to a specific plant species. Therefore, the picture drawn by phytoliths could be quite vague. Photo credit to handout of Pro.

item.title: Major climate events since late Pleistocene
item.description: Late pleistocene Oldest Dryas cooling (18000-14700BP) Bolling-Allerod warming (14700-12700BP) Younger Dryas cooling (12700-11700BP) Holocene 8.2 Ka cooling (8400-8000BP) Most influential cooling event during Holocene with a scale that is half of YD event. In China, we have Xinglongwa and Jingtoushan culture by that time. 4.2 Ka drought (4200BP-2200BP) This drought might put an end to Chinese Longshan culture, old kingdom of Egypt and Akkadian Empire.

item.title: On the birth of culture-historical archaeology
item.description: The following is my essay for a class instructed by professor Yan Pan in Fudan University. The class is based on A History of Archaeological Thoughts by Bruce G.Trigger. Hellen Sheng Professor Yan Pan A History of Archaeological Thoughts April 27, 2023 On the birth of culture-historical archaeology The dramatic social transformation in the late nineteenth century catalyzed the evolution and variation of archaeology ideology. Culture-historical archaeology became undoubtedly the most important method and theory among all.

item.title: !! A clever case study: zooarchaeology as circumstantial evidence of the origins of metallurgy
item.description: I recently read the “The origins of metallurgy: distinguishing stone from metal cut-marks on bones from archaeological sites”, which turns out to be an excellent demonstration of the usage of circumstantial evidence in the investigation of the origins of metalluurgy All photos came from The origins of metallurgy: distinguishing stone from metal cut-marks on bones from archaeological sites . Reference: Greenfield, H.J. 1999. The origins of metallurgy: distinguishing stone from metal cut-marks on bones from archaeological sites.

item.title: Anth 207x: Why bipedality?
item.description: I really like the edX course Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College, and I took a series of notes to this course. This article is based on my notes. Why we are bipedal creatures? There are various hypothesis: Temperature: The environment in East African is hot and relatively dry, and it’s easier for a bipedal to stay cool during the day.

item.title: Anth 207x: Ardipithecus Model
item.description: I really like the edX course Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College, and I took a series of notes to this course. This article is based on my notes. Ardipithecus is divided into two separate species based on dental and mandibular evidence: Ardipithecus kadabba, dates back to about six million years ago Ardipithecus ramidus, dates back to 4.

item.title: The earliest possible hominins: Orrorin tugenensis_osteology (7)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. The fossile of Orrorin tugenensis was also discovered in 2001. They lived sometime 6 million years ago in Tugen Hills region, Rift Valley, Kenya. The femur The most significant fossil of Orrorin tugenensis is a proximal femoral fragment becuase some features of this femur indicate that they might be bipedal.

item.title: The earliest possible hominins: Sahelanthropus_osteology (6)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. Discovered in 2001, Sahelanthropus was found in the desert of the Lake Chad basin in Central Africa. Why we say that Sahelanthropus mgiht be a member of hominins? There are several osteological evidence to support this hypothesis :

item.title: Why is the P in BP set at 1950?
item.description: I used to think that the reason to set the ‘present’ in BP at 1950 is because of the fact that 1950 is quite close to the discovery year of radiometric dating method. That statement is a truth, but not the whole story. Here is the reason that is much more profound: Nuclear bomb testing during the Cold War greatly disturbed the composition of the atmosphere and led to carbon-14 bomb pulse in 1963.

item.title: The earliest possible hominins: summary table_osteology (5)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. As we already know that chimps are not our ancestors, then who is? Any evidence of the earliest possible hominins? Currently, there are three candidates we know: Earliest possible hominins Name Place Date Sahelanthropus tchadensis Lake Chad Basin, Central Africa 6-7 mya Orrorin tugenensis Central Rift Valley, East Africa 6 mya Ardipithecus kadabba & ramidus Ethiopia & Kenya, East Africa 4-6 mya These candidates show somewhat reduced canine size and obligate or habitual bipedality.

item.title: How does bipedality influence our skeleton: tibia, pelvis and others_Osteology (4)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. Less curved tibia Compared with the chimp’s tibia, human tibia is less curved and less flexed. This is because we human beings exclusively load our tibia from an anterior/posterior direction but chimps knuckwalk quadrupedally. Chimps do a lot of different activities where tibia get involved like climing the tree.

item.title: How does bipedality influence our skeleton: femur_Osteology (3)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. Being bipedality is a tremendous shift. It involves changes of entire skeleton: Femur: 1. Bicondylar angle Being bipedal means we walk on one leg for every step and this means great weight and pressure on our legs.

item.title: Anth 207x: Dating method
item.description: I really like the edX course Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College, and I took a series of notes to this course. This article is based on my notes. Relative dating method 1.Geo-chronology: Correlate the age of different sedimentary layers across locations, particularly distinctive sedimentary layers like volcanic ash falls 2.Bio-chronolog: identify sequences based on fossils contained within these layers. For example, specific fossils are found across different locations.

item.title: How eating habit impacts skull_osteology (2)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. I mentioned strong canine in primates in my last blog, so what a strong canine can lead to? Actually, it will exert great influence on the structure of canium. Prominent snout. Roots of canines extend up into the rostrum resulting in more prominent snout on the skull.

item.title: Anth 207x: How to know when was the LCA?
item.description: I really like the edX course Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College, and I took a series of notes to this course. This article is based on my notes. As we talked before that chimps and human being evolve from common ancestor, but who can we know when latest common ancestor (LCA) lived? The answer lies in the molecular clock. In 1960s, geneticists found that differences in some protein structures were accumulating at a near constant rate through time, which made the time estimation of LCA possible.

item.title: Anth 207x: Miocene: the age of apes
item.description: Miocene (a period between 22 million years ago and 5 million years ago) is sometimes known as “The Age of Apes”. A great diversity of apes lived on various continents of our planet during Miocene and the environment and the climate of the world was quite different from today. During Miocene, the Mediterranean Sea used to be an open corridor of ocean during instead of a closed body of water. It thus connected the Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean, allowing tropical forests to grow throughout Eurasia, not limited to tropical regions.

item.title: Eating habit: canine and honing complex_osteology (1)
item.description: As I find osteology extremely interesting, I decide to write a special series for osteology based on my notes of Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College. In order to eat raw meat, apes developed strong canians together with a honing complex. Honing complex is a complex that (1) the lower canines project into the diastema between the upper canine and the lateral incisor and (2) the upper canine projects into the diastema between the lower canine and the lower third premolar.

item.title: Anth 207x: Is evolution directional?
item.description: I really like the edX course Anth 207x: Introduction to Human Evolution lectured by Professor Adam Van Arsdale of Wellesley College, and I took a series of notes to this course. This article is based on my notes. My understanding of evolution: Lego though holes By definition, evolution is “the heritable changes in a population through time”. It seems like that evolution has a direction (for example: from simple to complex), but it is NOT the case.

item.title: Misunderstandings: chimps are our ancestors/ our ancestors look like chimps
item.description: Thanks to Darwin’s theory of evolution, now we know the fact that human beings are not created by god. However, many people hold the view that (1) chimps are our ancestors and (2) our ancestors look like chimps. These are misunderstandings. Firstly, as what I wrote in my 2020-01-07 blog, Pan is the sister clay to Homos. Roughly 7 million years ago, chimps and human beings split from evolutionary tree and evolved in their own directions.

item.title: Distinguish BP, BC, AD, BCE and CE
item.description: What are the difference among BP,BC,AD,BCE and CE? Chart below helps. Photo credit to https://www.artobatours.com/articles/archaeology/bp-bc-bce-ad-ce-cal-mean/ AD: Anno Domini, i.e. “year of our Lord”, Christian era in the Gregorian calendar BC: Before Christ, pre-Christian era in the Gregorian calendar. CE: Common Era/Current Era, equivalent to AD, secular emphasis. BCE: Before Common / Current Era. BP: Before present (1950), date based on radiometric dating techniques.
